DOC.HEAD: Benham Sworn In as First Black on Georgia's Highest Court
DOC.TEXT: A judge who grew up in a public housing project fought back tears as he was sworn in as the first black to serve on the Georgia Supreme Court. Robert Benham said his family ``knew this day would come. They knew there was nothing we couldn't do and ... nothing that could hold us down.'' Benham, a Court of Appeals judge for 5{ years, was named to the state's highest court earlier this month by Gov. Joe Frank Harris, and was given the oath of office Thursday during ceremonies at the Capitol. During an acceptance speech, he had to fight back tears when he declared his joy that his parents not only lived to see the ceremony, but were able to participate in it. He said his success showed that a person ``can be born like I was, raised in public housing ... and rise to the statehouse on Capitol Hill.'' Benham, 43, succeeds Justice Thomas O. Marshall, who is retiring at the end of this month. The appointment lasts only through November, when the court seat will be up for election.
